posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
This is an update release of WPILib for the 2024 season. This release has a number of quality-of-life bugfixes.
Upgrading from earlier 2024 releases is easy: simply download and run the new install...

This is an update release of WPILib for the 2024 season. This release has a number of quality-of-life bugfixes.

Upgrading from earlier 2024 releases is easy: simply download and run the new installer and it will update your current installation. If you already have the 2024 WPILib vscode installed, it will detect it and you can simply click “next” for that installation step. After installation, vscode will prompt you when opening your robot project whether you want to upgrade it to this version. Note that using the installer is required to get the new version of desktop tools such as Shuffleboard.  This release is compatible with both 2024_v2 versions of the RoboRIO image. Mac note: if upgrading from 2024.1.1, it is necessary to manually remove the 2024.1.1 version of AdvantageScope before running the installer in order for the new version to be installed.

Note: After updating to 2024.3.2, the deploy process will deploy an updated JRE to your robot on first deploy.  This means the first deploy will take a little longer than usual.

The documentation for WPILib is located at https://docs.wpilib.org/ (if you have trouble accessing this location, FIRST Robotics Competition Control System — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation is an alternate location with the same content).

If you’re new to FRC , start with Getting Started .

WPILib is developed by a small team of volunteers and the FIRST community .

Several changes were made to address reports of robot code not immediately restarting following an uncaught exception or native crash:

“wpi::Now() not initialized” error is now fatal and immediately crashes by ThadHouse

An uncaught Java exception now immediately exits by PeterJohnson

JRE updated to not report memory allocation info, as this can hang by PeterJohnson

JRE error log reporting timeout shortened from 120 seconds to 2 seconds by PeterJohnson

Fix position feedback latency compensation by brettle

Fix arm characterization crash by calcmogul

Fix crash on negative feedforward gains by calcmogul

Fix wrong position Kd with unnormalized time by brettle

AdvantageScope updated to 3.2.1 by jwbonner

Add structured data support for DifferentialDriveWheelPositions by DeltaDizzy

LinearSystemId: Don’t throw if Kv = 0 by calcmogul

Use shift key to enable docking features by PeterJohnson

[wpiunits] Fix Distance class javadocs to state the correct dimension by DeltaDizzy

Add docs for features not supported on PDH (NFC) by sciencewhiz

Remove unused private variables by calcmogul

posts.name: Tom Winter
posts.cooked: Should we be upgrading if we have a competition this weekend, or only if we have been having issues?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: That’s a risk-based decision that’s really up to you.  We generally always recommend upgrades (otherwise we wouldn’t be releasing them).  The changes in this update relative to actual code operation are very minor (as you can see from the changelog) and should be low risk (note you can always downgrade back).  The main benefit is if your code crashes (for any reason), it will be far more likely to come back automatically with no manual intervention.  If you run into an issue like that at an event, the CSA will likely recommend you update.

posts.name: gartaud
posts.cooked:
Thanks for the release and your advice on upgrading or not.

What is the recommended procedure to downgrade if we ever wanted to?

Thanks!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
If you’re using version control, it’s really easy, just revert the commit you made when you did the upgrade.

It’s pretty easy manually too, just change the version number that’s near the top of build.gradle.

The above is for a robot project.  Downgrading desktop tools requires running the older installer.
